Anecdotes of a Wandering Veterinarian – the beginning

} ?>

Douglas Rae  |    June 25, 2017  |    Douglas Rae  |    0

Most students who go to Veterinary College see themselves one day settling into a busy but contented life of general practice. I was no different. I was born into a veterinary family in Yorkshire and the natural thing to do was to follow in the family footsteps. I had never thought of doing anything else.

But whilst at University I was severely bitten by the travel bug. This was largely due to my twin brother, who at London University (I was at Edinburgh) became acquainted with several useful people in the world of shipping. And during the long University holidays (ideal for long voyages) I found myself signed-on to paint the derricks and scrub the decks of worthy vessels bound for exotic places.

First was Greenland with its ice-bergs and Eskimos to whose spectacular shores we traveled in a Danish ice-breaker which managed to get itself well and truly stuck in the pack ice for days.
Then came a 3 month trip around the West Coast of Latin America: Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Chile. Here we managed to make ends meet by selling whisky (bought on the ship for about £5 a bottle, “smuggled” ashore and sold at more than 3 times the price). And it here that I became captivated by the life and color of the tropics. Everything was so exotic, so different and so much more exciting than listening to the moans and groans of Yorkshire pig farmers.

The appetite, once whetted, had to be slaked and so came the time of my graduation when I offered my services to V.S.O (Voluntary Service Overseas). It was a relatively easy way to get back to those beloved tropics. V.S.O. can send you anywhere in the world to do just about anything. Whilst awaiting news of my posting I spent the time picturing myself in a little hut off the Orinoco – so you can imagine my disappointment when I was told to go to Nigeria!

  Working Overseas  veterinarian traveling work vso
